verb.description: Push or pull a hard or sharp implement across (a surface or object) so as to remove dirt or other matter.
examples: rinse off the carrots and scrape them

verb.description: Rub or cause to rub by accident against a rough or hard surface, causing damage or injury.
examples: he smashed into the wall and felt his knee scrape against the plaster
she reversed in a reckless sweep, scraping the left front fender

verb.description: Narrowly pass by or through something.
examples: there was only just room to scrape through between the tree and the edge of the stream

verb.description: Copy (data) from a website using a computer program.
examples: all search engines scrape content from sites without permission and display it on their own sites

noun.description: An act or sound of scraping.
examples: he heard the scrape of his mother's key in the lock

noun.description: A procedure of dilatation of the cervix and curettage of the uterus.
An embarrassing or difficult predicament caused by one's own unwise behavior.
examples: he'd been in worse scrapes than this before now

phrases: aboard the ship, a nice girl scraped acquaintance with me
And then they pretend to scrape acquaintance with us again, said the lady.
People have to be scraping the barrel when they have to break into a charity shop and its very sad.
They are scraping the barrel when they resort to the mindless attack made in the newspapers.
The senseless killing of several citizens in a cruel heartless manner is indicative of our little country scraping the bottom of the barrel of human kindness.
origin: Old English scrapian scratch with the fingernails, of Germanic origin, reinforced in Middle English by Old Norse skrapa or Middle Dutch schrapen to scratch.
